1125906434384732160.text:
The final twist on this silliness is that the other icon, the one for a job that completed successfully?
It's called "blue.png".
It looks like this.pic.twitter.com/aLwhfFpwNM

1125906215563739136.text: so each pixel is two pixels (obviously) and therefore the image is being rendered at a nice round number, 115.191 pixels.

1125905980133232641.text: or at least it would be if I wasn't running on a high-DPI monitor with firefox, which means my "layout.css.devPixelsPerPx" is being computed as 2, which means that for every "1px" unit a CSS page tries to render it actually measures two pixels.

1125905743704551424.text:
no it turns out if you go to the computed size panel you'll see that the image itself is getting shrunk down PAST ZERO and rendering at negative 0.005 pixels.
So the final size is 57.5955px by 57.5955px.pic.twitter.com/4X2ycIb7ST

1125905432294318080.text:
which if we render, we'll find out is an 18x18 pixel version of that icon we saw in the first place.
but oh yeah, the padding. this is being rendered as a background... so the actual final size is 57.6 pixels?
No. Not so fast.pic.twitter.com/ldQIomfLcf

1125905021789294593.text: and it turns out there is! there's another rule specifically targeting images named "red.png" and it changes them to this inline data: URL, which turns out to be a 212-byte SVG image.pic.twitter.com/9CdvVu8Op3

1125904825596571648.text:
So it turns out the CSS here is overriding it to be, uh, 0 pixels by 0 pixels.
So "invisible", in other words.
And it's setting it up to have padding of 57.6 pixels on the left and top... 
And that's all. There's no more on this particular rule, so there has to be something elsepic.twitter.com/k5qrsdFJ64

1125904595241168896.text:
and you get this.
well, ok, that's clearly a failure icon but it's not remotely the right one.
it's also the wrong size, too. this is 48x48 pixels, which is... what the style said.
but it's not being drawn at 48x48 pixels. Let's check the CSS...pic.twitter.com/tmTtkJPjPv

1125904366890700800.text:
and OK, this HTML isn't too complicated, it's pretty much what you'd expect.
I don't know why they use style= instead of width=/height= but maybe it's nicer that way somehow. and they set alt, tooltip, and title, which seems overkill, but yeah, fine. So let's click that PNG URLpic.twitter.com/Qu0kSHDDoi

1125858874903285760.text: and just to avoid being accidentally offensive: if it's not clear by now, the joke isn't that I'm depressed, it's that this is called the "Beck Depression Inventory," and these are all sad-sounding Beck song/album titles.

1125856998946250752.text: like a "here's some files and a JPEG for the label, and mail it to this address" service.

1125161607464505344.text:
BTW, for anyone still wondering:
yes, the soviet union did pay their canadian radioactive cleanup bill.
they only paid half, though.

1125161231948533765.text: those things are heavy, after all.

1125161184263454720.text:
and before someone foolishly suggests that conventional power plants like coal or oil or hydroelectric would be much safer, let me set you straight:

a coal power plant falling out of the sky would also be very dangerous

1125160668137607168.text:
the moral of the story is DON'T PUT NUCLEAR REACTORS IN SPACE OR ON PLANES

Keep them in power plants where you can make them safe and efficient and where there's no risk of them falling out of the sky.

1125160009040449536.text:
they found 12 large pieces, one of which was radioactive enough to kill you within hours if you stayed in contact with it. 
The Canadian government then billed the USSR under the terms of the 1972 Space Liability Convention about 6 million Canadian dollars for the cleanup costs.

1125159614339661824.text: Usually it just put the core in a lower orbit than expected or dumped it into the ocean, but Kosmos 954 re-entered with the core intact in 1978 over northern Canada. a US/Canadian team had to search 124,000 square kilometers for radioactive material.pic.twitter.com/9SMNHkCYdo

1125158815245012992.text:
So they were designed to eject their reactor core into a higher orbit at the end of their lifespan, so it wouldn't re-enter as quickly as the rest of the satellite. 

That didn't always work, though. Space is hard.

1125158479776194560.text: They were nuclear-powered because they had to be in a low-earth-orbit to detect boats, but because of the atmosphere density there the solar panels would have caused so much drag that they wouldn't be able to orbit for long.

1125157806955323392.text: Whereas the Soviets launched 31 nuclear powered spy satellites for the Upravlyaemy Sputnik Aktivnyy (Controlled Active Satellite) project, to monitor NATO and merchant ships using radar.pic.twitter.com/fcTwgKpOfQ

1125157330620829697.text:
BTW, if the idea of a nuclear reactor on a plane sounds like an amazingly terrible idea, you'll love to hear that there's been nuclear reactors launched into space.
The US one was called SNAP-10A and was launched in 1965 (and is still in orbit, though non-functional)pic.twitter.com/AlSbzikNHv

1125155415291875329.text: nuclear power plants do have accidents from time to time, to be sure, but they never fall out of the sky when that happens.

1125155293132800000.text:
which is probably a really good thing for the continued health of the planet, to be honest.
nuclear reactors can be very great safe things, but they probably should not be flying around on planes. that's not a good idea.

1125155124689555456.text:
The Soviets were working on something similar, of course.
Theirs was the Tupolev Tu-95LAL, tested in the mid-60s.
They similarly were mainly testing the shielding, and while that supposedly was fine, they too didn't continue to building this into a real atomic-powered-plane.pic.twitter.com/O0qYz6J29x

1125154610799230977.text: you could basically launch it and then it stays up until the engines fall off or the pilots run out of food.

1125154484764565505.text:
But the neat thing (from the perspective of the cold war, at least) is that these planes would have amazing endurance.
if it only takes a sugar cube's worth of fuel to fly from new york to london, imagine how long you could stay in the air!

1125154244678434816.text:
Plus they weren't really sure how to land the thing and change crew and such.
They'd be irradiating their airstrips and ground crew.

1125153759363907584.text: The end result was that they had managed to shield it well enough that the crew weren't going to be affected by the radiation coming off the reactor, but if they ever crashed that'd be a major contamination problem.

1125153483223470080.text: They ended up flying it 47 times over 215 hours of total flight time, with the reactor running for 89 of those hours. They never hooked the reactor up to the engines, though, it was still being powered by the regular jet fuel.

1125153165072928768.text:
Which isn't an entirely hypothetical silly example, by the way.
In the 40s and 50s the US Air Force worked on the Nuclear Energy for the Propulsion of Aircraft project. 
They put a reactor on a modified B-36 and did successfully fly it.pic.twitter.com/OihlkEaduY

for comparison, I checked out http://justfly.com  and they tell me I can get a 5:55am economy flight on May 21st from London (Heathrow) to New York (JFK) for 279$
(or 212£)pic.twitter.com/60oYvwbg81

1125145411956531200.text: So that works out to 46,480$. Or, since we're flying out of London, 35,344£.

1125144216735080448.text: So before our flight, we gotta go buy 332,000 AA batteries.

1125144131032895488.text:
but it's okay, Rich Hall is a comedian, not an engineer or mathematician. He was just off by a bit.

How many batteries do we need per person, then?
Well, our 200 batteries gave us 2.8 MJ, we need 4,649 MJ, so we just need to increase the number by a factor of 1660.

1125143767252516865.text:
or to put that in the same unit, that's 2.8 megajoules.

And how many did we calculate we need? We need 4,649 megajoules.
Oh dear.

1125143568803217408.text:
but wait, we've got 200 of them! 
So that's 2,800 kilojoules (per person) of battery power, and we need to use this to fly new york to london.

1125143294533558272.text:
so a watt is a joule a second, and the commonly used kilowatt-hour is equivalent to a thousand watt device running for an hour. 
But this isn't 3.9 kilowatt hours, it's 3.9 watt-hours. 
So that's a total of 14,000 joules, or 14 kilojoules per battery.

1125142339591081984.text:
So now we need to figure out how much energy is in 200 batteries.
So AA batteries can be all different sorts of chemistries, but generally you'd mean a standard un-rechargable alkaline.
They have a maximum energy (under perfect conditions) of 3.9 Watt-hours.pic.twitter.com/N2VwwmTjsZ

1125141756939366400.text:
in any case, jet A-1 has an energy density of 34.7 megajoules per liter.
So that means you need 4,649 megajoules per person to fly london to new york.pic.twitter.com/lGQ3kQs5Vr

1125141180226756608.text:
Side note: Jet A1 weighs 0.8 kilograms a liter, so for one person flying new york to london they need 107 kilograms of fuel, or 235 pounds.

Which means for many passengers flying trans-atlantic, the fuel required to transport them across the ocean weighs more than they do.

1125140819680174081.text:
And what kind of fuel does the 747 us?
It uses Jet-A or Jet-A1. Jet A1 is the international version of Jet-A. Since we're going london to new york and not the other way around, we'd expect Jet-A1.

1125140505363267587.text:
and a 747 carries around 500 people, so we need to divide that per-person, as each person flying london to new york is going to be bringing 200 batteries, right?

so that's 134 liters per person (or 35 gallons)

1125140151963795456.text:
And this page (on "http://howstuffworks.com ") says that a 747 gets about 5 gallons a mile (or 0.2 miles per gallon) or 12 liters a kilometer)

So that means you'd need about 67,000 liters of fuel to fly london to new york.pic.twitter.com/loB6SkVTvf

1123818346850521094.text:
so I've put on my baffled pants here.
Here's the datasheet, if anyone wants to look it over and hopefully prove me wrong. I didn't see anything about this being an optional big-memory mode or anything, it's just how the chip works: (PDF link)
https://www.beck-ipc.com/download.php?file=96 …

1123818106391023620.text:
And if you're gonna do that, why not just use an ARM chip or something?
They're far more powerful, common, and cheaper.

1123817839092170752.text: So the one big advantage I can think of for this chip running an 80186, specifically that it's a well-understood architecture with a lot of legacy software that can run on it, HAS JUST BEEN LOST. You now have to custom-code everything for this weirdo mutant version of x86.

1123817647903322112.text: which is fine, I guess, but it fundamentally breaks an assumption that basically all x86 code since 1978 has been making

1123817526742458373.text: Instead, because of the 8-bit shift instead of 4-bit, 0:256 and 1:0 overlap.

1123817361151352832.text:
so on any 80*86 machine from the original IBM PC's 8088 right up to whatever weird Core i7 I'm running today, addresses 0:16 and 1:0 point to the same place. (if we're in 16-bit mode) 

They don't on the IPC@CHIP.

1123817080065859585.text:
well it has a 24-bit address space, and it gets that by FUNDAMENTALLY CHANGING HOW THE 8086 REAL MODE WORKS.
Instead of segments being combined with an offset by shifting right 4 bits, it shifts 8 bits.pic.twitter.com/dPFSKueAIX

1123816853632180224.text:
But (nearly) all DOS software has to be written to understand this or Things Will Break Very Badly.

So now that we understand (hopefully) what the 8086/8088/80186 does, what the heck does the IPC@CHIP do?

1123816560190210048.text: So this is all kinda weird but it's how x86 works and we have to live with it. The 286 (and much more so the 386) introduced protected mode, then we can have a linear or page-mapped address space, and pretend this segmentation stuff doesn't exist for the most part.

1123816221567344641.text: which means that on real mode x86, the addresses 0:16 and 1:0 point to THE SAME PLACE IN MEMORY.

1123816017950584832.text:
So this means if you have the selector 0 and the offset 0, that points to a linear address of 0, but if you have a selector of 1 and the offset 0, that doesn't point to a linear address of 65536, as you'd expect.
it points to a linear address of 16.

1123815827537633280.text:
So what this means is that they overlap. They overlap a lot.
In practice, the segment selector only gets you 4 extra bits of address space.pic.twitter.com/8qotp5WpU2

1123815474867974145.text:
but no, because they're not added together like you may think. Instead of combining them by having the segment selector be the top 16 bits of a 32bit address and the offset being the bottom 16 of a 32bit address..

They're the top & bottom 16 of a 20bit address.

1123815241320734722.text:
Basically the way the memory works is that every address is made up of two 16-bit words. They're combined together, resulting in a 20 bit address.

Yeah, that math doesn't make sense. Shouldn't that give you a 32-bit address?

1123814956464582657.text:
So to explain what exactly it does, you have to understand how real mode memory addressing works.
So the 8088/8086/80186 are 16-bit processors, right? 16 bits is their native word size.
But their addressable memory is 20 bits wide, at 1mb.

1123814543342428161.text:
The Beck IPC@Chip... does not do extended memory. It can't: You need a 286 or higher for that, and it's a 186.
So does it use expanded memory? That'll work all the way back to the 8088. So it totally could use it....

BUT NOPE!

1123814172498780160.text: So your 16-bit real mode program gets the memory advantages of 32-bit protected mode's 24-bits of address space, at the small cost of slower access and some more complicated access patterns (since you still have a window & a driver to deal with)

1123813959805673472.text:
and DOS doesn't run in 32-bit protected mode, it runs in 16-bit real mode, which is limited to the 1mb.
So what extended memory does is provide a window and a device driver to access it, and the driver just switches to protected mode, does the memory copy, then switches back.

1123813722747744257.text:
Extended memory also has a window, but under the hood it's done differently:
It takes advantage of the fact that 286 and later processors have a bigger 24-bit address space, but only in 32-bit protected mode.

1123813362171817987.text:
So your program had to be written specially to use Expanded Memory, it didn't just get it for free. 
Eventually Extended Memory became available and  expanded memory could be emulated with it, so Expanded Memory fell out of favor.

1123813011003727872.text:
So you'd have a machine with 2mb of memory (640k on the motherboard, and 1408k on a memory-expansion board).
Instead of directly accessing the memory above 640k directly, your program would tell the EMS driver "I want the memory at X", and the page frame would become that

1123812659051278336.text: There's a specification called EMS, for Expanded Memory Specification. It provides a way for a 8086/8088/80186 machine to access more than 1mb of RAM by using a "page frame", which was a 64kb section of memory that could be pointed at a larger memory space.

1123812057504198658.text:
It was the 286 that moved up to a 24-bit address space, letting it use up to 16mb of RAM. This is 186, which can't.

So how's it do it? well don't worry, there are obvious ways.

1123811685997920256.text:
OK SO yesterday I was gushing over this neat 80186-based system-on-a-chip but there was one lingering question: what's up with the RAM?
It has 8mb of RAM. That's fine... except 80186 can only address up to 1mb of RAM.https://twitter.com/Foone/status/1123322470360944641 …

create repo, create branch, create PR from branch to master : FINE
fork repo, create branch, create PR from branch to master: NOPE

1123717081353072640.text: I don't know if this isn't documented or if it's just not documented well or I'm just an idiot and didn't read the docs closely enough, but this took me forever to figure out.

1123716670055485450.text:
So it turns out if you dig into the source of the pull request model: 
every pull request is linked to a hidden issue, which is why there are gaps in the issue numbering. 
So you can use the API for manipulating comments on an issue by just using it on pull requests.

1123716356418035713.text: You get pull request #1, and Issue #2.pic.twitter.com/AQcuOt5XDt

1123716252944482304.text:
and there's a hint to where it is if you make a pull request on a new repo and then make an issue.
you get pull request #1 and Issue #1, right?

WRONG!

1123715954586869760.text:
Christ, this took me forever to figure out.
OK SO YOU WANT TO DO STUFF WITH PULL REQUESTS IN GITEA:
but there's no API for that. There's an API for comments on issues, right? but not pull requests. 

... but that's not exactly true. There's an API, just not where you expect itpic.twitter.com/QV1kIzCiqb

1123676805565702145.text:
You use Apache. Just put a .htaccess file into http://catb.org/jargon/html/  and add the following contents:

AddCharset ISO-8859-1 .html

BAM! it's done, it works now.

1123676067317809153.text:
So the page is correctly saying it's ISO-8859-1, but the HTTP header is saying it's UTF-8.
Obviously both can't be correct, and the browser has to pick one. Apparently they're picking the HTTP header, which is the wrong one.

1122646891714338817.text: Annoyingly it seems a lot of fancy gaming keyboards implement the N-key-rollover not through the report protocol but through a proprietary one implemented in their Gamer Mode Awesome Cool Drivers, so you end up not getting it on Linux, only Windows, and only with their driver.

1122646223129722880.text: so most of the time your N-key-rollover keyboard is actually only a 6-key-rollover keyboard.

1122646147464437760.text: fun fact: there's two USB-based keyboard protocols in use, the boot protocol and the report protocol. boot protocol is usually the default, and it limits you to 6-key-rollover (other than modifier keys)

1122645906283614208.text:
which means THE EXACT SAME THING BECAUSE THIS KEYBOARD ONLY HAS 104 KEYS
they're just saying it that way to sound more impressive

1122645816093470721.text: unless you're corsair, and you think that instead of just saying "n-key" meaning "any number of keys", you say "104-key rollover"

1122645706752180224.text:
and if a keyboard is fully isolated, you can push any number of keys at once and have them all register.
This is called n-key rollover, or NKRO.

1122645552691200001.text: so you can measure a keyboard by how many keys worth of rollover it has. 2-key-rollover is basically the bare minimum but without 3-key-rollover or more you can get problems with certain words in english if you type them fast and captialized, like "MY" is often a problem.

1122645306351296512.text: rollover is the ability of a keyboard to register multiple keys at the same time, and requires either full isolation diodes or careful design of the keyboard matrix to get better than 2-key-rollover without ghosting (where unintended phantom keys will be pressed)

1121935193013493760.text: I've talked about it before, but GPS was originally also a military-only system, and the plan only changed to make it generally accessible after the USSR shot down a passenger jet that was off course.https://twitter.com/Foone/status/1009174372190339072 …

1121933454826852352.text:
The reason, by the way, that submarines needed accurate satellite positioning is so that they could precisely target their Submarine-launched ballistic missiles. 

Yay, Cold War?

1121933055180939264.text:
it's hard to tell because there's not a lot of documentation about this, because military and all.
But it was also used by the French nuclear submarines, and most of the info (and that picture) of the TRW-130 comes from this page about their usage of it:
http://www.feb-patrimoine.com/projet/cae/cae_militaire.htm …

1121932761890037763.text:
The Transit system ended up being used right up until GPS was functional enough to completely drop it, which happened in 1996. 
I don't think the TRW-130 lasted that long, though.

1121932554683072512.text:
It was a 15bit (yes, 15) processor running at 330 kilohertz, featuring 8192 words of RAM, or 15.3 kilobytes. 
It wasn't a microchip, it was discrete transistors. (because it was 1958)

1121931030674284545.text: So TRW (who did a lot of the miniaturization work on ICBMs) designed the TRW-130, aka the AN/UYK-1. A computer just small enough to fit through 25" diameter submarine hatches.pic.twitter.com/botQ0ZgLnn

1121930485075046400.text: in other words, there was literally no existing computer they could get INTO a submarine in 1958, at least not without completely taking it apart and re-assembling it again. They didn't want to do that, so they needed a new computer.

1121930315528720384.text:
but there were some important details that had to be worked out before this system could be used:
1. To calculate your position based on the radio signals of a bunch of satellites, you need a computer, and a reasonably fast one.
2. SUBMARINES HAVE 25" DIAMETER HATCHES

1121929736240844801.text:
Here's a fun reason to design a computer I just discovered:
So in the late 1950s the US Navy was experimenting with the Transit series of satellites, to provide satellite positioning for submarines.
They worked similar to the later GPS satellites.pic.twitter.com/2yq6TFI2lZ

1121926153076232193.text: It's from 1986, btw. somehow that number got dropped while I was editing that tweet. Anyway, here's the original post:https://twitter.com/BBCArchive/status/1117767025114226693 …

1.48×10^21 light years. As the galaxy only has a radius of 7.5 x 10^4 light years, this means our galactic pancake would be a black hole.

1121851238922932224.text:
alternatively if you were to scale up the pancake to the milky way's diameter, it would be 2000 light years thick.

and would contain 2.1495×10^67 calories, assuming no syrup.

1121849992581275648.text:
our ISO standard pancake is 1 cm thick
the milky way, if shrunk down to pancake size, would be 0.2 cm thick.
Therefore, the milkyway is THINNER THAN A PANCAKE
(specifically, it's 5 times thinner)

1121849781360312321.text:
so if we decrease the average thickness of the milky way (2000 light years) by 9.461×10^21, we end up with... 

0.2 centimeters!pic.twitter.com/lLafy8lkuu

1121849451532808192.text:
step 3: calculation
the milky way is 1.419×10^23 cm in diameter. so we need to decrease the diameter by a factor of 9.461×10^21, while decreasing the thickness equivalently

1121848487916654592.text:
step 2:
how big is milky way
wikipedia says 150–200 kly (kly=1000 light years) in diameter
and on average, 2 kly thick

1121848166968545280.text:
step 1:
how big is pancake
simple english wikipedia (oh dear) says an average size for a US restaurant pancake is 14cm (5") diameter, and 1cm (0.3") thick.

1121222753804120064.text:
ATX has a momentary button that sends a "please power on" signal to the PSU.
AT just has a big bulky thing that switches power to the PSU on and off. 
So I could mount an AT power supply into the ATX case, and the motherboard fit, but the button was a problem

1121222558244728832.text:
my own personal stupid-5.25"-bay tale is something I sadly don't have a picture of.
I was building a server once and I had an AT power supply, but only ATX cases on hand. (I also had no money)
That's a problem because AT and ATX use different power buttons.

Nixie tubes are these neat types of vacuum tubes where they stack up each of the numbers separately and it just illuminates the needed letter.

1121209776988229632.text: The early mavica cameras pretend their resolution is 640x480 but that's just upscaled from the 570x490, because they're built on a camcorder sensor.

1121208834179997696.text: so @nucknyan had asked if the transfer cable worked with Sony Mavica cameras, and while I don't think it would, these specs mean that the resolution of the printer is almost exactly the same as a mavica's native CCD resolution: 570x490.
